questions.question: Question 1: Which among the following are indications to shift a patient to the burn center?
questions.explanation:
> 5% BSA burnt is not an indication to send a patient to the burns center. Guidelines for referral to a burn center: • Partial-thickness burns greater than 10% body surface area (BSA). • Burns involving the face, hands, feet, genitalia, perineum, or major joints. • Third-degree burns in any age group. • Electrical burns, including lightning injury. • Chemical burns. • Inhalation injury. • Burn injury in patients with complicated pre-existing medical disorders. • Patients with burns and concomitant trauma in which the burn is the greatest risk. If the trauma 
is the greater immediate risk, the patient may be stabilized in a trauma center before transfer to a 
burn center. • Burned children in hospitals without qualified personnel for the care of children. • Burn injury in patients who will require special social, emotional, or rehabilitative intervention.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following are false regarding first-degree burns?

options.c: Protective functions of the skin are intact
options.d: No residual scar after injury heals

questions.explanation:
First-degree burns involve only the epidermis, are painful, but do not blister, protective functions 
of the skin are intact and heals without a scar. Second-degree burns have dermal involvement and are extremely painful and blister. Third-degree burns are leathery, painless, and non-blanching. 1070 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: A man accidentally took a bath with overheated water. A few hours later, he developed the 
given lesion on his shoulders and chest. Following spontaneous rupture 3 days later, the base 
of the lesion was erythematous and blanches on touch. What is the time taken by these 
wounds to heal? 1058 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of second-degree superficial burns. They usually heal with 
minimal scarring in 10–14 days unless they become infected. Second-degree burns are divided into two types: • Superficial Dermal burns are erythematous and painful, blanch to touch, and often blister. They 
heal in 10–14 days. • Deep dermal burns involve the reticular dermis, appear more pale with erythmatous regions, do 
not blanch to touch, but remain painful to pinprick. They heal in 4–8 weeks.

questions.question: Question 4: Which layer is involved in blister formation in a superficial partial thickness burn?
questions.explanation:
The papillary dermis is involved in blister formation in a superficial partial-thickness burn. First-degree burns involve only the epidermis, with pain, redness, and mild swelling. Second-degree (partial thickness) burns involve the epidermis and some parts of the dermis (also 
known as partial-thickness burns). Further divided into: • Superficial second-degree burns - involves the upper part of the dermis (papillary) and shows 
pain, blisters, and severe swelling. • Deep second-degree burns - extends up to the reticular layer of the dermis and appears more 
pale and mottled, does not blanch to touch, but remains painful to pinprick. Third-degree or full-thickness burns involve the full thickness of the dermis and subcutaneous 
tissue. Fourth-degree burns involve deep structures such as muscle and bone. 1071 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient has presented to you with a burn wound as seen in the image below. With regards 
to Jackson's zones of tissue injury, which of the following statements is false? 1059 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Area 2 is the most severely burned portion
options.b: The outer area of a burn is called the zone of hyperemia
options.c: Vasodilation is seen in the area 3
options.d: Area 1 heals with minimal or no scarring

questions.explanation:
Vasoconstriction (not vasodilation) is seen in red region or zone of stasis (marked zone 3). Jackson zones of tissue injury following burns has three zones: • The zone of coagulation is the most severely burned portion and is typically in the center of the 
wound. • Peripheral to that is a zone of stasis, with variable degrees of vasoconstriction and resultant 
ischemia. • The last, outermost area of a burn is called the zone of hyperemia, which will heal with minimal 
or no scarring and is most like a superficial or first-degree burn. It is characterized by vasodilation 
from inflammation surrounding the burn wound.

questions.question:
Question 6: While examining the burns on this patient, you find a lack of sensation and capillary refill at 
the burnt site. What is the degree of burn?
questions.explanation:
The characteristic features of full-thickness burns (third-degree burns) are lack of sensation in the 
burned skin, lack of capillary refill, and a leathery texture that is unlike normal skin. Deep dermal and full-thickness burns require excision with skin grafting for the patient to heal 
the wounds properly.

questions.question:
Question 7: A chemical engineer burnt his fingers as shown in the image while working with hydrofluoric 
acid. What is the most appropriate way to manage this patient?

options.a: Topical application of calcium gluconate gel along with ECG monitoring
options.b: Irrigation with Dakin's solution followed by surgical excision of the burn site
options.c: Immediate intrarterial injection of calcium gluconate
options.d: Copious irrigation with normal saline and application of mafenide acetate

questions.explanation:
Following irrigation of the burn site, topical application of calcium gluconate gel along with ECG 
monitoring is the most appropriate management. 1072 
Sold by @itachibot Hydrofluoric acid is the strongest inorganic acid and it can cause liquefaction necrosis of deeper 
tissues (since the acid is highly lipophilic). Pain out of proportion to physical examination is a 
hallmark finding in HF burns. Systemic absorption of fluoride ions can result in intravascular 
chelation of calcium causing hypocalcemia. Depletion of calcium causes inhibition of the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, leading to 
hyperkalemia and subsequent life-threatening arrhythmias. Therefore ECG monitoring is 
imperative. ECG abnormalities that can occur include prolonged QTc (from hypocalcemia) 
and QRS widening (from hyperkalemia). Following copious irrigation of the burn site with water, the mainstay of treatment is with topical 
application of calcium gluconate gel. If the pain does not subside, or if systemic signs ensue, an 
intraarterial injection of calcium gluconate can be given in the affected extremity.

questions.question:
Question 8: 20% of a patient's total body surface area was burnt from an overhead electric supply line. 
What is leading cause of death in such burns?
questions.explanation:
The leading cause of death in electrical injuries is cardiac arrest. This is because alternating 
current injuries interfere with normal cardiac pacing. The electricity itself does not usually cause significant underlying myocardial damage. So 
resuscitation, if successful, should be lasting. The domestic electricity supply comprises a low voltage alternating current.

questions.question:
Question 9: ABG of a patient with extensive burns shows pH: 7.29, pCO2: 38mmHg, HCO3: 16.5, and 
elevated lactate of 5mmol/L. As part of initial fluid resuscitation, which fluid would be the 
best to initiate in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The best fluid used for burns is Ringer’s lactate or Hartmann’s solution. Ringer lactate (crystalloid) is a mixture of sodium chloride, sodium lactate, potassium chloride, 
and calcium chloride in water. It prevents metabolic acidosis that may occur in burns. Crystalloids are said to be as effective as colloids for maintaining intravascular volume and are 
given during the initial 24 hours. Option A: Normal saline may be used, but large quantities of saline can cause hyperchloremic 
metabolic acidosis, worsening this patient's existing acidosis. Option D: Human albumin solution is a colloid. Colloids should be ideally be given after the first 
12 hours of burn because before this period, the massive fluid shifts cause proteins to leak out of 
the cells.

questions.question: Question 10: An adult whose both lower limbs are charred along with genitalia has      burns.
questions.explanation:
Using Wallace’s Rule of 9, the % total burn surface area: • One lower limb = Thigh (9%) + leg (9%) = 18% • Genitals = 1% 1073 
Sold by @itachibot Hence, in this patient, one lower limb+ other lower limb + genital = 18% + 18% + 1% = 37%.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 3-year-old is brought with superficial and deep second degree burns on his chest. What is 
the most accurate method to assess the total body surface area involved ? 1062 
Sold by @itachibot

options.c: Using the child's palm as reference

questions.explanation:
Lund and Browder chart gives a more accurate accounting of the true burn size in children. Unlike the Wallace rule of nines, the Lund and Browder chart takes into consideration the age of 
the person, by decreasing percentage BSA (Body Surface Area) for the head and increasing 
percentage BSA for the legs as the child ages, making it more useful in pediatric burns.

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient comes to your clinic with a superficial partial-thickness burn. Which of the 
following statements regarding the management is false?

options.a: Superficial burns generally do not require the use of topical antibiotics
options.b: Blisters on second degree burns should not be burst
options.c: All topical antibiotics retard wound healing
options.d: Facial burns of the same degree will require a hydrocolloid dressing

questions.explanation:
Facial burns do not require a hydrocolloid dressing. Exposure therapy (no dressings are applied 
over the wound) is typically used on the face and head. All topical antibiotics retard wound healing to some extent so they are used only in second or 
third-degree burns or wounds, which have a high risk of infection. Blisters on second-degree burns should not be burst as they may cause an infection. Topical treatment of deep burns: • 1% silver sulphadiazine cream • 0.5% silver nitrate solution • Mafenide acetate cream • Silver nitrate, silver sulphadiazine and cerium nitrate

questions.question:
Question 13: While starting fluid resuscitation on a patient with burns, it is important to keep in mind that 
all of the following parameters will be decreased, except:
questions.explanation:
1074 
Sold by @itachibot Capillary permeability and afterload is increased after severe burns. Significant burns is associated with massive release of inflammatory mediators, both in the wound 
and in other tissues. These mediators produce vasoconstriction and vasodilation, increased 
capillary permeability, and edema locally and in distant organs. Cellular and humoral immunity are decreased in burns (increased risk of infection). Changes in various systems in burns: CVS • Massive edema • Increased afterload • Decreased venous return • Decreased cardiac output Renal • Low volume concentrated urine • Decreased urinary sodium • Myoglobinuria • Renal ischemia • Acute tubular necrosis • Acute renal failure GI • Reflex Ileus • GI Ulcers (Curling’s Ulcer) Endocrine and Metabolism • Increased glucagon, cortisol • Protein catabolism • Ureagenesis • Lipolysis • Increased gluconeogenesis • Lactic acidosis Hematological • Anaemia • Initial thrombocytopenia then thrombocytosis • Decreased capacity of neutrophil phagocytosis • Overall lymphopenia • Relative increase in T-Suppressor Cells 1075 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient has rushed to your clinic after she spilled hot tea on her hand. What should be the 
ideal temperature of the water used to cool her injuries?
questions.explanation:
In temperate climates, cooling should be at about 15 °C, and hypothermia must be avoided. 
Moreover, studies show that ice cold water increases tissue damage. Water at 15 °C provides analgesia and delays the microvascular damage in burns. It should occur for a minimum of 20 minutes and is effective up to 1 hour after the burn injury. Particularly important in scalds.

questions.question:
Question 15: While fixing faulty wiring, an electrician sustains the given burn. Which of the following is 
false? 1064 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Electric burns are usually third degree burns
options.b: Urine output should be monitored for volume and deposits
options.c: ECG should be monitored even in low voltage burns
options.d: Fluid requirement is less as compared to other burns

questions.explanation:
Fluid requirement is more as compared to other burns. All electric burns are managed by 
resuscitation at 4mL/Kg/%TBSA (which means 4mL for every Kg for every %TBSA). This is 
double what the ATLS guidelines advise for other burns as electrical burns may cause 
myoglobinuria and acute kidney injury. Most of the electrical burns are of severe degree and cause third-degree burns. The fluid resuscitation is done to ensure urine output of 100 mL/hr in adults and 1–1.5 mL/kg/hr 
in children < 30 kg, until the urine clears from pigmentation. The IV fluid is then titrated down 
to ensure the urine output of 0.5 mL/Kg/hr. Electrical injuries are usually divided into low and high-voltage injuries. • Low voltage injuries cause small, localized, deep burns. • High voltage injuries damage by flash (External burn) and conduction (Internal burn) The myocardium may be directly damaged without pacing interruption. Thus, ECG must be 
monitored for arrhythmias.

questions.question:
Question 16: A man with severe burn injuries is admitted to the ward. Proton-pump inhibitors are started. 
Which ulcer is being prevented?
questions.explanation:
Proton pump inhibitors are used in burns patients to prevent Curling's ulcer. It is an acute gastric 
erosion that is a complication from severe burns when reduced plasma volume leads to ischemia 
and cell necrosis of the gastric mucosa. Marjolin’s Ulcer is squamous cell carcinoma occurring in a long-standing burn scar or any chronic 
ulcer. Cushing’s ulcer is a gastric ulcer occurring in elevated intracranial pressure. Buruli's Ulcer is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 34-year-old electrician sustains electrical burns while at work. On arrival he is 
hemodynamically stable, and he is placed on ECG monitoring and initial fluid resuscitation is 
initiated. His urine is collected for routine labs and appears as below. Which of the following 
lab abnormalities may be seen in this patient? 1065 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
1076 
Sold by @itachibot The tea-colored urine in the clinical vignette in the setting of an electrical injury is suggestive of 
rhabdomyolysis following electrical burns. Elevated creatine kinase is seen in rhabdomyolysis. AC injuries are more commonly seen and this current creates tetany within the muscles. This 
sustained contraction can lead to muscle injury and resulting in rhabdomyolysis and 
myoglobinuria, presenting as tea-colored urine. Damage to the underlying muscles in the affected limb can also cause the rapid onset of 
compartment syndrome. The release of the myoglobins will cause myoglobinuria and subsequent 
renal dysfunction. Therefore, during the resuscitation of these patients, efforts must be made to 
maintain a high urine output of up to 2 mL/kg body weight per hour. Biochemical features of rhabdomyolysis are: • Elevated CPK, BUN, Cr • Hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia.

questions.question:
Question 18: A woman, weighing 58 kg, has second-degree burns covering 20% of the total body surface 
area. Which of the following formulae would you use to calculate the amount of fluid to be 
given?

options.a: Percentage of burns × weight (kg) × 2 = volume in mL
options.b: Percentage of burns × weight (kg)/2 = volume in mL
options.c: Percentage of burns × weight (kg) × 4 = volume in mL
options.d: Weight + 1500 ml/m2×BSA burnt = volume in mL

questions.explanation:
According to the latest ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) 10th edition 2018, resuscitation 
formula for second and third-degree thermal burns in the first 24 hours is given by the following 
equation: Total percentage body surface area burned × weight (kg) × 2 = volume (mL). Half this volume is given in the first 8 hours and the second half is given in the subsequent 16 
hours. This has been recommended to reflect concerns about over-resuscitation when using the 
traditional Parkland formula. Adequacy of fluid resuscitation is assessed by monitoring for a urine output of 0.5-1.0 mL/kg/hr. However, in cases of electrical burns, the formula is: Total percentage body surface area burned× weight (kg) × 4 = volume (mL). Parkland and Modified Parkland formula: • Parkland's formula for resuscitation in the initial 24 hours is given by = Total percentage body 
surface area × weight (kg) × 4 = volume (mL). • Modified Parkland's formula provides more specific recommendations for the second 24 hours, 
advising colloid infusion of 5% albumin at the amount of 0.3-1.0/mL/kg/%BSA/hr. The 
management of the first 24 hours remains the same.

questions.question:
Question 19: Which of the following formulas will you use to calculate the amount of albumin to be 
administered to a patient with burns?
questions.explanation:
The most commonly used colloid-based formula is the Muir and Barclay formula: • 0.5 × percentage body surface area burnt × weight = one portion • A total of six portions are given in 36 hours • Three portions: One portion for every 4 hours in 12 hours. 1077 
Sold by @itachibot • Two portions: One portion for every 6 hours in the next 12 hours. • One portion: Remaining one portion in the last 12 hours. Colloid-based resuscitation using the Muir-Barclay formula results in the administration of lower 
volumes of fluid than Parklands formula and carries a lower risk of complications from 
over-resuscitation. However, colloids (4.5% Albumin) are deferred for the first 8 hours when 
capillary permeability is highest and the benefit is questionable. So, the 36-hours schedule of the 
Muir and Barclay formula would begin after the first 8 hours of burn. Options A and C: Parkland formula and Evan's formula are used to calculate the crystalloid 
volume to be given in the first 24 hours. Option D: Wallace's rule of nine is used to calculate the percentage of the burnt body surface area 
(%TBSA).

questions.question:
Question 20: A patient was brought to the hospital after being rescued from a burning house where he was 
trapped for 4 hours. The patient has a few minor burns but is coughing extensively. His voice 
is hoarse and he is able to drink water with some difficulty. What is the safest strategy of 
management?

options.b: O2 therapy with well-fitting face mask

questions.explanation:
For a patient who presents with a history or suspicion of inhalational burn injury, elective 
endotracheal intubation is the safest strategy. Delay can make intubation very difficult because of airway edema and can lead to airway 
obstruction. One should be ready to perform an emergency cricothyroidotomy if intubation is 
delayed. Recognition of the potentially burned airway: • A history of being trapped in the presence of smoke or hot gases • Burns on the palate or nasal mucosa, or loss of all the hairs in the nose • Deep burns around the mouth and neck American Burn Life Support (ABLS) indications for early intubation include: • Signs of airway obstruction (hoarseness, stridor, accessory respiratory muscle use, sternal 
retraction) • The extent of the burn (TBSA > 40%–50%) • Extensive and deep facial burns • Burns inside the mouth or difficulty swallowing • Significant edema or risk for edema • Signs of respiratory compromise: Inability to clear secretions, respiratory fatigue, poor 
oxygenation or ventilation • Decreased level of consciousness where airway protective reflexes are impaired • Anticipated patient transfer of large burn with airway issue without qualified personnel to 
intubate en route

questions.question:
Question 21: A 12-year-old boy presented to the OPD with a scald injury of his arm. The lesion was pink, 
oozing, and painful to moving air and touch. Which of the following is the most appropriate 
management?
questions.explanation:
1078 
Sold by @itachibot Scald injury (damage from contact with hot liquids) that appears pink in colour, has oozing, and 
pain is suggestive of a 2nd-degree burn (i.e. partial-thickness burn). Collagen dressing is the most 
appropriate management for this injury. The best dressing for burn wounds is skin; collagen is a good substitute for skin, especially in 
partial-thickness burns. For full-thickness burns, sequential excision and grafting should be 
considered. Initial treatment for burns includes cleaning burnt areas and removing loose dead skin. Blisters 
are de-roofed and an appropriate dressing is applied. Biological dressing (collagen dressings, amniotic membrane, etc.) is the preferred dressing 
material, especially in partial thickness burns. If this is not available then a non-adhesive dressing like paraffin gauze impregnated with silver 
sulfadiazine (SSD) cream, colloidal silver, ionic silver cream, or silver nitrate cream can be 
applied. Since increased resistance to SSD has recently emerged, it should be judiciously used and 
reserved for deep dermal, full thickness, infected, and old neglected burns.

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following antibiotics will be most appropriate for managing the burn wound in 
this patient? 1067 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows a burn eschar. Among the given topical antibiotics, only mafenide acetate 
penetrates burn eschar to reach the interface with the patient's viable tissue. This agent has the disadvantage that it is quite painful on any partial thickness areas, and it is a 
carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and can potentially cause metabolic acidosis.

questions.question:
Question 23: A 58-year-old homeless man was brought to a PHC in Himachal Pradesh during late winter. 
He was found unresponsive. His rectal temperature was 23 degrees C, pulse was not 
measurable, heart rate was 30 per minute and respiratory rate was 6. Rewarming with an 
electric blanket was started. Which organ is most susceptible to dysfunction in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hypothermia. The heart is the organ most sensitive to 
cold and is subject to ventricular fibrillation or asystole when the temperature drops to 21–24 °C. 1079 
Sold by @itachibot Hypothermia affects the dissociation of oxygen from hemoglobin, so less oxygen is released to the 
tissues. Other complications are coagulopathies and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC),

questions.question: Question 24: Sweating is usually absent in
questions.explanation:
Sweating is usually absent in classic (epidemic) heatstroke (CHS). Heatstroke occurs as a result of an imbalance between heat production and heat dissipation 
(sweating). The skin is pink or ashen and sometimes, paradoxically, dry and hot. Dry skin in the 
presence of hyperpyrexia is virtually pathognomonic. It is of 2 types: • Exertion-induced heat stroke is seen in people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion 
in high temperatures, usually without adequate training. • Sedentary heatstroke (CHS) is a disease of elderly or infirm people whose cardiovascular systems 
are unable to adapt to the stress of a hot environment and release sufficient heat such that body 
temperature rises. Heat Cramps: • These are painful spasms of voluntary muscles which follow strenuous work in a hot 
atmosphere. • Caused by loss of water and salt in profuse sweating. Heat exhaustion/heat prostration: • Collapse without any elevation of body temperature • Occurs due to exposure to high temperature in closed environment • Precipitated by muscular exercise and unsuitable clothing • Extreme exhaustion with peripheral vascular collapse with scanty sweating.

questions.question:
Question 25: A marathon runner was training on a hot afternoon when he experienced leg cramps and 
dizziness. He fainted and was taken indoors by his coach. His temperature was 104.8 F, pulse 
126 per minute and BP 90/60 mm of Hg. Despite an hour of rest and cold sponging, he did 
not improve. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?
questions.explanation:
The heat stroke may be either exertion induced or sedentary heatstroke. 1080 
Sold by @itachibot Heat stroke occurs as a result of an imbalance between heat production and heat dissipation. • Exertion-induced heat stroke is seen in people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion 
in high temperatures, usually without adequate training. • Sedentary heat stroke is a disease of elderly or infirm people whose cardiovascular systems are 
unable to adapt to the stress of a hot environment and release sufficient heat such that body 
temperature rises. The body temperature must be measured rectally. Treatment is rapid cooling by spraying the patient with water at 15 °C. 1081 
Sold by @itachibot Wound Healing, Tissue Repair & Scar
